document.docAuthor: Dijkstra, Klaas-Douwe B., Kipping, Jens & Mézière, Nicolas
document.masterDocTitle: Sixty new dragonfly and damselfly species from Africa (Odonata)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Sixty new dragonfly and damselfly species from Africa (Odonata)

paragraph.heading:
Tragogomphus grogonfla Dijkstra
sp. nov. – Western Horntail
( Type
Photo 43
,
Photo 57
,
Fig. 27
)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Dijkstra ( 2007 ) proposed to restrict the genus
Tragogomphus Sjöstedt, 1900
to the type species
T. aurivillii Sjöstedt, 1900
from Cameroon and the closely similar
T. ellioti Legrand, 2002
from Gabon. Populations in the Upper Guinea are genetically distinct from
T. ellioti
and differ clearly from both species in the male appendages (
Fig. 27
).

Holotype
♂
.
RMNH.INS. 503176
, Sierra Leone , Eastern Province ,
Gola Forest, Sembehun (abandoned village)
, sandy stream and adjacent spring area in forest,
219–233 m
a.s.l. (
7.7598 ° N
10.7174 ° W
),
11 -iii- 2011
, leg. K.-D.B. Dijkstra & A. Dayeker , RMNH
.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 27. Male appendages in dorsal (left) and lateral view (right) of two
Tragogomphus
species.

Type Photo 43 .
Holotype of
Tragogomphus grogonfla
sp. nov. , RMNH.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Seven unique haplotypes (n= 16 ) nearest to but distinct from
T. ellioti
from Gabon, although
T. aurivillii
from Cameroon was not sampled.
Name alludes to the pronunciation of ‘dragonfly’ by Mr Edward Rose, who assisted the author in Liberia (noun in apposition).

Sandy and gravelly headwater streams between 150 and 800 m a.s.l. in rainforest in Liberia and adjacent Sierra Leone. The first true
Tragogomphus
species found outside Cameroon and Gabon.
